title: Synthetic Recap
body:
HOUSTON (AP) — In the grand, aging theater of The Summit, with the echoes of championships still fresh, Hakeem Olajuwon authored another masterpiece for the Houston faithful. On a night when the offense flowed through him with historic purpose, "The Dream" delivered a staggering 49-point, 25-rebound performance to will the Houston Rockets to a 115-109 victory over the Los Angeles Clippers.

This was not merely a win; it was an annihilation by a single, unstoppable force. Olajuwon, moving with the grace and power that defined his era, was simply unguardable. He carved up the Clippers' defense with a dizzying array of spins, fades, and authoritative finishes at the rim. Each of his 49 points was a hammer blow, and his 25 rebounds, an astounding 10 on the offensive glass, ensured the Rockets feasted on second chances all night.

While the Clippers fought valiantly, led by Loy Vaught's 24 points and 16 rebounds, they had no answer for the tidal wave in the paint. Every double-team was diagnosed and dissected, every single coverage exploited. Olajuwon was the offense, the defense, and the undeniable heart of the Rockets.

In supporting roles, Clyde Drexler added 19 points and Eddie Johnson provided a spark off the bench, but they were satellites orbiting a brilliant, dominant sun. The final stat line—49 and 25—transcends the box score, joining the pantheon of individual regular-season performances that define NBA legend. It was a night where one man, Hakeem Olajuwon, didn't just play a game of basketball; he conquered it.
